unnormalised: Planning meetings in India can be a bit of a circus, right? Especially when you're trying to coordinate with everyone from your boss in Mumbai to your teammates in Chennai. You need to be mindful of all sorts of things - not just time zones, but also public holidays, festival days, and everyone's penchant for taking a chai break exactly when you planned to start. Getting everyone on the same page can feel like herding cats!
normalised: Planning meetings in India can be a bit of a circus, right? Especially when you are trying to coordinate with everyone from your boss in Mumbai to your teammates in Chennai. You need to be mindful of all sorts of things - not just time zones, but also public holidays, festival days, and everyone's penchant for taking a chai break exactly when you planned to start. Getting everyone on the same page can feel like herding cats!

unnormalised: One of the biggest hurdles is definitely the time difference. Trying to find a slot that works for folks in Kolkata (GMT+5:30) and someone calling in from, say, London (GMT+0) means a whole lot of juggling. I remember this one time we tried to schedule a call for 3:00 PM IST. It was a nightmare figuring out who would be having lunch, who'd be just starting their day, and who'd be winding down!
normalised: One of the biggest hurdles is definitely the time difference. Trying to find a slot that works for folks in Kolkata (G-M-T plus five hours thirty minutes) and someone calling in from, say, London (G-M-T plus zero hours) means a whole lot of juggling. I remember this one time we tried to schedule a call for three o'clock P-M I-S-T. It was a nightmare figuring out who would be having lunch, who would be just starting their day, and who would be winding down!

unnormalised: Then there's the festival calendar to contend with. Good luck trying to get anyone to attend a meeting on 14/01/2025, which is Makar Sankranti! Or even close to Diwali. People are busy with family, festivities, and generally being unavailable. You’ve gotta check those public holiday lists before even *thinking* about scheduling anything. Even regional holidays differ, so keep that in mind.

Even regional holidays differ, so keep that in mind.

unnormalised: Internal deadlines add a layer of complexity. “EOD” is thrown around a lot, but whose EOD are we talking about? If the deadline is "EOD 15/07/2024" the Bombay team assumes it's their EOD, while the Delhi team assumes theirs. Clarifying the Timezone makes all the difference.
normalised: Internal deadlines add a layer of complexity. "E-O-D" is thrown around a lot, but whose E-O-D are we talking about? If the deadline is "E-O-D fifteenth july two thousand and twenty four" the Bombay team assumes it is their E-O-D, while the Delhi team assumes theirs. Clarifying the Timezone makes all the difference.

unnormalised: The best way to tackle this chaos is to use a scheduling tool, no doubt. Something that automatically converts time zones, considers holidays, and ideally, integrates with everyone's Google Calendar. Polls also work really well. Throw out a few time options and let the team vote. It is easier to find out that everyone is free at 11 AM IST on 20/08/2024 using these tools.

unnormalised: Ultimately, a little bit of flexibility and good humour goes a long way. Remember, everyone's just trying to get their work done. A little empathy and willingness to prepone or postpone slightly will make the whole scheduling process way less painful. And hey, if all else fails, blame it on the chai!
